question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
If the product $\left(4^5\right)\left(5^{13}\right)$ is written as an integer, how many digits are in this integer?
inference:
First, simplify the expression: $$\left(4^5\right)\left(5^{13}\right)=\left(2^2\right)^5\left(5^{13}\right)=2^{10}5^{13}$$ 

Then, calculate the number of digits using the formula: $$d(x)=\left\lfloor\log_{10}(x)\right\rfloor+1$$ where $d(x)$ is the number of digits in $x$.

$$d(2^{10}5^{13})=d\left(2^{10}\left(5^3\right)^4\cdot5\right)=d\left(2^{10}\left(125\right)^4\cdot5\right)$$

$$d\left(2^{10}\left(125\right)^4\cdot5\right)=d\left(2^{10}\left(125\right)^3\cdot5^{16}\right)=d\left(2^{10}\left(125\right)^3\cdot\left(5^4\right)^4\right)$$

$$d\left(2^{10}\left(125\right)^3\cdot\left(5^4\right)^4\right)=d\left(2^{10}\left(125\right)^3\cdot5^{16}\right)$$

$$d\left(2^{10}\left(125\right)^3\cdot5^{16}\right)=d\left(2^{10}\cdot5^{15}\cdot5\right)=d\left(2^{10}\cdot5^{16}\right)$$

$$d\left(2^{10}\cdot5^{16}\right)=\left\lfloor\log_{10}(2^{10}5^{16})\right\rfloor+1=\left\lfloor\log_{10}(2^{10})+\log_{10}(5^{16})\right\rfloor+1$$

$$d\left(2^{10}\cdot5^{16}\right)=\left\lfloor10\log_{10}(2)+16\log_{10}(5)\right\rfloor+1$$

$$d\left(2^{10}\cdot5^{16}\right)=\left\lfloor10(0.3010)+16(0.6989)\right\rfloor+1$$

$$d\left(2^{10}\cdot5^{16}\right)=\left\lfloor3.010+11.1824\right\rfloor+1$$

$$d\left(2^{10}\cdot5^{16}\right)=\left\lfloor14.1924\right\rfloor+1$$

$$d\left(2^{10}\cdot5^{16}\right)=14+1$$

$$d\left(2^{10}\cdot5^{16}\right)=15$$

Final Answer: \boxed{$15$}. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
By pairing up factors of 2 with factors of 5 to make factors of 10, the product may be written as \begin{align*}
4^5\cdot5^{13} &= 2^{10}\cdot 5^{13} \\
&= (2\cdot5)^{10}\cdot5^3 \\
&= 125\cdot 10^{10}.
\end{align*} `125' followed by 10 zeros has $10+3=\boxed{13}$ digits.

question:
First, simplify the expression: $$\left(4^5\right)\left(5^{13}\right)=\left(2^2\right)^5\left(5^{13}\right)=2^{10}5^{13}$$ 

Then, calculate the number of digits using the formula: $$d(x)=\left\lfloor\log_{10}(x)\right\rfloor+1$$ where $d(x)$ is the number of digits in $x$.

$$d(2^{10}5^{13})=d\left(2^{10}\left(5^3\right)^4\cdot5\right)=d\left(2^{10}\left(125\right)^4\cdot5\right)$$

$$d\left(2^{10}\left(125\right)^4\cdot5\right)=d\left(2^{10}\left(125\right)^3\cdot5^{16}\right)=d\left(2^{10}\left(125\right)^3\cdot\left(5^4\right)^4\right)$$

$$d\left(2^{10}\left(125\right)^3\cdot\left(5^4\right)^4\right)=d\left(2^{10}\left(125\right)^3\cdot5^{16}\right)$$

$$d\left(2^{10}\left(125\right)^3\cdot5^{16}\right)=d\left(2^{10}\cdot5^{15}\cdot5\right)=d\left(2^{10}\cdot5^{16}\right)$$

$$d\left(2^{10}\cdot5^{16}\right)=\left\lfloor\log_{10}(2^{10}5^{16})\right\rfloor+1=\left\lfloor\log_{10}(2^{10})+\log_{10}(5^{16})\right\rfloor+1$$

$$d\left(2^{10}\cdot5^{16}\right)=\left\lfloor10\log_{10}(2)+16\log_{10}(5)\right\rfloor+1$$

$$d\left(2^{10}\cdot5^{16}\right)=\left\lfloor10(0.3010)+16(0.6989)\right\rfloor+1$$

$$d\left(2^{10}\cdot5^{16}\right)=\left\lfloor3.010+11.1824\right\rfloor+1$$

$$d\left(2^{10}\cdot5^{16}\right)=\left\lfloor14.1924\right\rfloor+1$$

$$d\left(2^{10}\cdot5^{16}\right)=14+1$$

$$d\left(2^{10}\cdot5^{16}\right)=15$$

Final Answer: \boxed{$15$}. I hope it is correct.

ground_truth:
By pairing up factors of 2 with factors of 5 to make factors of 10, the product may be written as \begin{align*}
4^5\cdot5^{13} &= 2^{10}\cdot 5^{13} \\
&= (2\cdot5)^{10}\cdot5^3 \\
&= 125\cdot 10^{10}.
\end{align*} `125' followed by 10 zeros has $10+3=\boxed{13}$ digits.
